questions.question: The cat is hiding ___ the table.
questions.explanation: 'Under' indicates position below something. The cat is below the table, concealed from view.

questions.question: We reached the station ___ time.
questions.explanation: 'On time' is a fixed phrase meaning punctually, at the scheduled time. Not early, not late.

questions.question: She is very good ___ mathematics.
questions.explanation: 'Good at' is the correct collocation for skills and subjects. We always say 'good at' something, not 'good in'.

questions.question: The book was kept ___ the shelf.
questions.explanation: 'On the shelf' indicates position on top of a surface. Books are placed on shelves.

questions.question: He has been absent ___ Monday.
questions.explanation: 'Since' is used with a point in time when using present perfect. 'Since Monday' = from Monday until now. NOT 'on Monday'.

questions.question: The train will arrive ___ 9 o'clock.
questions.explanation: 'At' is used with specific times. We say 'at 9 o'clock', 'at noon', 'at midnight'.

questions.question: She was born ___ 15th August.
questions.explanation: 'On' is used with specific dates. We say 'on 15th August', 'on Monday', 'on Christmas Day'.

questions.question: The shop is closed ___ Sundays.
questions.explanation: 'On' is used with days of the week. 'On Sundays' (plural) means every Sunday.

questions.question: I have been waiting ___ two hours.
questions.explanation: 'For' is used with a duration of time (two hours, three days, etc.). 'Since' is used with a point in time.

questions.question: The bird flew ___ the window.
questions.explanation: 'Through' indicates movement from one side to the other of an opening or enclosed space.

questions.question: He jumped ___ the river to save the child.
questions.explanation: 'Into' indicates movement from outside to inside. Jumping into water means entering it.

questions.question: The picture is hanging ___ the wall.
questions.explanation: 'On the wall' is used for pictures because they are attached to the wall's surface.

questions.question: She is afraid ___ dogs.
questions.explanation: 'Afraid of' is a fixed phrase. We say 'afraid of' something or someone we fear.

questions.question: He is interested ___ music.
questions.explanation: 'Interested in' is a fixed phrase. We say 'interested in' a topic, hobby, or activity.

questions.question: The book belongs ___ my sister.
questions.explanation: 'Belongs to' is a fixed phrase indicating ownership. Something belongs to its owner.

questions.question: We walked ___ the bridge to reach the other side.
questions.explanation: 'Across' indicates movement from one side to the other of a surface or area.

questions.question: The plane flew ___ the clouds.
questions.explanation: 'Above' indicates position higher than something else without touching. The plane was higher than the clouds.

questions.question: She divided the cake ___ her friends.
questions.explanation: 'Among' is used for distribution within a group of three or more. 'Between' is used for two.

questions.question: He sat ___ his two brothers.
questions.explanation: 'Between' is used when referring to two people or things. He was in the middle of his two brothers.

questions.question: The meeting will start ___ noon.
questions.explanation: 'At' is used with specific times including 'noon', 'midnight', 'dawn', 'dusk'.

questions.question: She is fond ___ chocolates.
questions.explanation: 'Fond of' is a fixed phrase meaning to like something. You are always 'fond of' something.

questions.question: The children ran ___ the garden.
questions.explanation: 'Around' indicates movement in a circular path or in various directions within an area.

questions.question: He lives ___ the fifth floor.
questions.explanation: 'On' is used with floors of a building. We say 'on the first floor', 'on the ground floor'.

questions.question: The dog was running ___ the car.
questions.explanation: 'Behind' indicates position at the back of something. The dog was at the back, following the car.

questions.question: She looked ___ the mirror.
questions.explanation: 'Look into' means to examine or investigate. When looking at a mirror, you look 'into' it to see your reflection.
